item.title: Maths
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

This wasn’t integration of logs - there were two separate questions. A question on the properties of logarithms and on definite integrals. But the strange thing is that I covered basic logarithms a long time ago, and integration of logarithms very shortly after basic integration strategies.

Now AS and A2 math courses are A Level? I’m having a hard time finding info on this…just curious as to how the English system compares to mine here in the US.

Read full topic

item.title: Maths
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I don’t think you quite have #1…

log5(4x + 3) - log5(x + 1) = 2

log5[(4x + 3) / (x + 1)] = 2

5^[log5[(4x + 3) / (x + 1)]] = 5^2

(4x + 3) / (x + 1) = 25

(4x + 3) = 25(x + 1)

4x + 3 = 25x + 25

21x = -22

x = -22/21

This is a strange answer as you cannot simply plug it into the initial function…but combining it as you did using the laws of logarithms works fine.

  1. I think I get what you’re asking…I’ll add in the limits later - you don’t need k yet really, so lets just work through the integration first

∫(x^2 - 2x + k)dx

(1/3)x^3 - x^2 + kx [1, 3]

[(1/3)(3)^3 - (3)^2 + k(3)] - [(1/3)(1)^2 - (1)^2 + k(1)]

[9 - 9 + 3k] - [(1/3) - 1 + k]

3k + 2/3 - k

2k + 2/3

But you’re told that the value of this definite integral is 26/3

2k + 2/3 = 26/3

2k = 8

k = 4

Hope that’s right - dunno if I understood the problem correctly.

Out of curiosity, what level math are you taking? I wouldn’t have thought that these would be taught too closely…

Read full topic

item.title: Maths
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

it isnt homework, but im doing some practice exam papers and have gotten stuck

  1. Solve the Equation
    log5(4x + 3) - log5(x + 1) = 2;

  2. Given that.
    (Integrate Range 1 - 3) x^2 - 2x + k = 26/3;
    Find k;
    Edit: k is a Constant;

help is appriciated;[br][size=1]Posted on: April 14, 2007, 10:06:48 AM[/size][hr]ok i solved the first,

log5(4x + 3) - log5(x + 1) = 2;

log5(4x+3)/(x+1) = 2;

log5 (3x + 3) = 2;

5^2 = 3x + 3

22 = 3x

x = 22/3

Read full topic
